## <i class="bi bi-diagram-2"></i> Reproducible Analysis Frameworks

Different research contexts require different reproducibility approaches.

::: {.panel-tabset}

### Computational Reproducibility

Computational reproducibility ensures others can rerun your analysis and obtain the same results.

**Core principles:**

<div class="orc-grid-tools">

<div class="orc-card">
<strong><i class="bi bi-code-slash"></i> Scripted Workflows</strong>

<ul>
<li>Avoid manual data manipulation</li>
<li>Use scripts instead of point-and-click</li>
<li>Document all analysis steps</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="orc-card">
<strong><i class="bi bi-gear"></i> Environment Control</strong>

<ul>
<li>Track software versions</li>
<li>Manage package dependencies</li>
<li>Use containers when appropriate</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="orc-card">
<strong><i class="bi bi-folder2-open"></i> Organized Structure</strong>

<ul>
<li>Consistent project organization</li>
<li>Relative (not absolute) paths</li>
<li>Clear file naming</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="orc-card">
<strong><i class="bi bi-arrow-clockwise"></i> Random Seeds</strong>

<ul>
<li>Set seeds for random processes</li>
<li>Document stochastic procedures</li>
<li>Enable exact replication</li>
</ul>
</div>

</div>

### Code Documentation

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-chat-left-text"></i> Inline Comments</summary>

Comments explain *why* you made decisions, not just *what* the code does.

**What to comment:**

- Rationale for methodological choices
- Explanation of complex algorithms
- Context for non-obvious code
- Known limitations or workarounds
- Citations to methods or papers

**What not to comment:**

- Obvious code
- Outdated information
- Sensitive information

</details>

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-journal-code"></i> README Files</summary>

README files are essential for understanding how to use your code repository.

**Required elements:**

- **Project title and description**
- **How to run the analysis**: Step-by-step instructions
- **Software requirements**: Language versions, dependencies
- **Input data**: Where to obtain or how to access
- **Output**: What files are produced
- **Project structure**: Explanation of directories

**Example:**
```markdown
# Analysis of Treatment Effects

## Requirements
- R version 4.3+
- Packages listed in renv.lock

## Running the Analysis
1. Install dependencies: `renv::restore()`
2. Run scripts in order: 01_preprocessing.R, 02_analysis.R
```

</details>

### Literate Programming

Literate programming combines code, results, and narrative text in a single document.

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="mortarboard"}
## Learn More: Literate Programming

[Introduction to Quarto](https://lmu-osc.github.io/introduction-to-Quarto/) (2.5h) - Create reproducible documents combining code, results, and prose.
:::

**Common tools:**

<div class="orc-grid-2col">

<div>

**Computational notebooks:**

- Jupyter Notebooks (Python, R, Julia)
- R Markdown / Quarto
- Observable (JavaScript)
</div>

<div>

**Benefits:**

- Results auto-update with code changes
- Combine analysis and reporting
- Output to multiple formats
- Facilitate reproducibility
</div>

</div>

**What to include in analysis notebooks:**

1. Introduction: Research question
2. Methods: Statistical procedures
3. Data loading: Source and preprocessing
4. Main analysis: Tests and models
5. Results: Tables and figures
6. Session info: Software versions

### Version Control & Collaboration

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-git"></i> Git Best Practices</summary>

Version control is essential for tracking changes to analysis code.

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="mortarboard"}
## Learn More: Version Control

- [Version Control with Git](https://lmu-osc.github.io/Introduction-RStudio-Git-GitHub/) (2h)
- [Collaborative GitHub Workflows](https://lmu-osc.github.io/Collaborative-RStudio-GitHub/) (1h)
:::

**Key practices:**

- Commit frequently with logical changesets
- Write meaningful commit messages
- Never commit large data files
- Never commit sensitive information
- Use branches for experimental analyses
- Tag releases for publications

**Good commit message:**
```
Add power analysis for sample size justification

- Implemented simulation-based power calculation
- Tested effect sizes (d = 0.3, 0.5, 0.8)
```

</details>

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-people"></i> Collaboration & Review</summary>

**Collaboration workflows:**

- **Centralized workflow**: Simple, one main branch
- **Feature branch workflow**: Each analysis on separate branch
- **Pull request review**: Review before merging

**Code review checklist:**

- [ ] Code runs without errors
- [ ] Methods match analysis plan
- [ ] Results reproducible on different machine
- [ ] Code well-organized and commented
- [ ] No sensitive data included

**What reviewers check:**

1. Functionality and correctness
2. Reproducibility
3. Readability and organization
4. Best practices

</details>

### Statistical Analysis & Quality

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-calculator"></i> Analysis Planning</summary>

Plan analyses before looking at outcome data to avoid biases.

**Analysis plans should specify:**

- Statistical tests to be used
- Variables and transformations
- Handling of missing data
- Outlier criteria and treatment
- Multiple comparisons corrections

**Exploratory vs. confirmatory:**

- **Confirmatory**: Tests specified in preregistration
- **Exploratory**: Additional analyses not prespecified
- Clearly label which is which

</details>

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-check-circle"></i> Quality Assurance</summary>

**Code quality practices:**

- Follow style guides (Tidyverse for R, PEP 8 for Python)
- Use automated styling tools (styler, black, lintr)
- Consistent naming conventions
- Descriptive variable names
- Limit line length (80-100 characters)

**Statistical consulting:**

Consider consulting for complex designs, advanced methods, or results interpretation.

::: {.callout-tip style="margin-top: 1rem;"}

:::

</details>

:::

## <i class="bi bi-clipboard-check"></i> Analysis & Collaboration Checklist

::: {.orc-gradient-box}

**Before Starting Analysis:**

<div class="orc-grid-2col">

<div>

- [ ] Analysis plan documented
- [ ] Project uses version control (Git)
- [ ] Directory structure organized
- [ ] Dependencies managed
</div>

<div>

- [ ] README file initiated
- [ ] Data dictionary available
- [ ] Code style guide chosen
- [ ] Collaboration workflow established
</div>

</div>

**During Analysis:**

<div class="orc-grid-2col">

<div>

- [ ] Scripts well-commented
- [ ] Commit changes regularly
- [ ] Random seeds set
- [ ] Intermediate results saved
</div>

<div>

- [ ] Analysis decisions documented
- [ ] Code reviewed by collaborators
- [ ] Results cross-checked
- [ ] Figures reproducible
</div>

</div>

**Before Sharing:**

- [ ] Code runs without errors on fresh environment
- [ ] README provides complete instructions
- [ ] All functions documented
- [ ] Session info captured
- [ ] Sensitive information removed
- [ ] Code peer-reviewed

:::
